Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of STS-PROM in Predicting Stroke and Neurocognitive Outcomes Post-TAVR

Trial_Design.evidence: Patient-level data were pooled from four prospective trials

Intervention.evidence: Participants were stratified into low (<4%), intermediate (4-8%), and high (>8%) STS risk groups.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether the Society of Thoracic Surgeons Predicted Risk of Mortality (STS-PROM) predicts stroke and neurocognitive outcomes following transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR).

Method_Outcome.evidence: At 30 days, high-risk patients had higher rates of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean STS score among patients with versus without stroke was similar (5.9 vs 5.1; p = 0.19).

Harms.evidence: high-risk patients had higher rates of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, myocardial infarction, acute kidney injury, bleeding, and vascular complications.

Trial_Registration.evidence: DEFLECT III (NCT02070731), NeuroTAVR (NCT02073864), REFLECT I (NCT02536196), REFLECT II (NCT02536196).
